Computer Program To Be Ousted?
By MIKE WEISSMAN
A decision by Arts and
Sciences Dean George Benton to
Withhold funds for additional
computer science faculty has
endangered the whole computer
science program, according to
computer professors.
Benton's decision, made on
October 28, is based on the
availability of short-term
funding for the Committee on
Computer Sciences over the next
five years.
Dr. Michael Flynn, one of the
two tenured faculty in the
program, predicts the eventual
phasing out of the entire
'program within a year and a half
when only three professors will
be left to handle the course load.

Dean George Benton—"I'm

be running this University."(see

This semester's new Master of
Science degree and the planned
undergraduate degree,
announced just three weeks ago,
will have to be dropped due to
the decision, according to Flynn.
Benton countered the
computer professor's arguments
simply. "From my point of view
the whole thing is that you don't
do things when you don't have
the money. We will not make
long term appointments on the
basis of short term money."
Henry Ledgard, Computer
Sciences, said, "We asked
Benton for no money now, but
for a commitment for University
support within five years if
financial conditions are
favorable."

Benton explained the
University had hired professors
in the lusher days of the 1960's
with money available for only a
limited period of time. After the
money ran out the University
had to fund the program or lose
the professors who had worked
for the term of the grant.
The Social Relations
department was originally
funded in this way with a large
grant from the Ford Foundation
that came due within the year.
The loss of that money had to
be covered by renewed
University support and outside
revenue.
The Committee on Computer
Sciences, which includes four
faculty appointments and five

faculty with joint appointments
in related fields, have a
two-faceted plan to win a
reprieve.
Flynn plans to contact
Academic Council members to
complain about the way the
decision was reached. Both he
and Ledgard are concerned that
the Academic Council failed to
enter in on the decision-making
along with the dean, and that
neither computer professors nor
a broad-based committee were
consulted by the dean.
"I was more disturbed by the
procedure followed in arriving at
the decision than by the decision
itself," said Flynn. Ledgard
echoed this view, "The decision
to phase out programs should be

Official Skepticism

S.C. Move Causes Concern
By DON LASSUS
Homewood administrators
have greeted the Student
Council's move to cut ties with
the administration with a degree
of skepticism and concern.
Expressing hope for
negotiations, administration
heads indicated their surprise at
the action taken at Monday
night's SC meeting, which broke
relations with the Homewood
administration until a new
governance system could be
developed giving students
decision-making power.
"I don't know if that is what
the students really want," said
Dean George Benton of the
demand for decision-making
powers. "The Student Council
doesn't impress me as the voice
of the students."
Benton stressed that the
Student Council could not
actually break all ties with the
administration on budgetary
considerations. "We collect the
money for the student activity
fee, and without it the Council
would have no funds to work
with," said Benton.
Benton indicated that
administration-connected

committees would continue to
function despite the Council's
request that student
representatives on such
committees resign their
positions. Benton was unsure of
the effects of withdrawal of SC
support from these committees.
Power Politics
Dean of Undergraduate
Studies Sigmund R. Suskind,
chairman of the Blue Kibbon
Panel on Education, expressed
disappointment with the
Council's action. "Without any
students on the Panel, the
effectiveness is greatly reduced.
"The Student Council
counters the lesson of power
politics with the move," Suskind
continued. "When you have an
important voice, you don't pull
out."
Suskind stated that the SC
stand "pulls the rug from under
a substantial increase in student
voice." He indicated that thus
far students on the panel have
been most effective. Suskind
plans to ask the undergraduate
representatives to remain on the
panel as independents.
"The Student Council has not
met with anyone and I'm not

sure of where we disagree," said
Provost Steven Muller. "In the
long run, no element in the
University can go it alone."

'Action'Plan: Students in Community

Joseph Blatchford

By HOWARD WEAVER
Johns Hopkins has been
selected as one of twenty
universities to receive federal
money to implement a
"University Year for ACTION"
program which will send
students out of the classrooms
and into the community.
The program, funded under
the auspices of ACTION (the
newly-formed "citizens-corps of
volunteers" including the old
Peace Corps, VISTA, and other
volunteer agencies), would send
30 Hopkins students to work as

volunteers in the surrounding
community, while earning a
semester's worth of academic
credit. Hopkins has received an
$11,566 planning grant to
develop details of the program.
The nature of the Hopkins
program has not yet been
finalized, but is being
coordinated through the
Hopkins Center for Urban
Affairs. The matter of academic
credit, a central concept of the
ACTION proposal, is being
considered by the Academic
Council.

Sol Levine, director of the
Center, envisions the program as
an extension of some existing
Hopkins projects, involving
undergraduates, grad students
and Medical School students.
"We hope to create an
interesting, exciting living
experience in this program," he
said.

volunteers, as well as part of the
administrative costs to the
University.

Larry Stearns: Energy In Levering Hall

By DAVID PICKALL
Larry-Steams has an office on
the second floor of Levering
Hall, just beyond the flood of
colors that is dedicated to
People and Chester's Place.
Larry's time at Hopkins is
divided between overseeing a
course dealing with the problems
of Juvenile Delinquency that is
sponsored by Dr. Wickwire, and
a Draft and Military counseling
service.

Talking with Larry is an easy
experience. Most people call him
just Larry: Mr. Steams would
somehow sound inappropriate.
Through the drift of a
conversation his answers are
always thoughtful, and his

sincere openness is conveyed by
his eyes as well as his words.
Quoting him seems a little
unfair, for his answers are long
with concern for a better
understanding, and quotes are at
best a summary.
While open and honest, there
is also a reserve about Larry, a
kind of secretiveness. He is a
quiet person. He smiles easily
but does not often laugh. He was
a clown at the Halloween party
in Levering last weekend,
complete with white face and
comic pantomime. He said he
enjoyed being a clown; he had
never been one before.
Larry graduated from
Hopkins with a Liberal Arts
degree in 1965. He concentrated
in Philosophy and specifically in
Ethics. Of his undergraduate
work at Hopkins, Larry says,
"We studied ethics, but in no
meaningful way considered the
applications of ethical decisions
outside an intellectual or
academic framework. The most
serious failing of my educational
background was that it didn't
really prepare me for any
community other than an
academic one."
From Hopkins, Larry went to
Bolivia as a rural community
development worker with the

Peace Corps. After two years in
Bolivia, he spent five months as
a Peace Corps recruiter on
college campuses in the South.
In 1967, draft legislation
precluded his work with the
Peace Corps and his accepting
admission to Union Seminary in
New York. As Larry puts it,
"The draft was unexpectedly
uncooperative." Deciding to
make the "best of a bad
situation," he enlisted in the
Navy, was trained as a Hospital
Corpsman, and stationed in
Annapolis.
The recuperating Vietnam
veterans in the Annapolis Navy
Hospital created an atmosphere
that allowed Larry to clearly
focus on the issues of the war.
He applied for a discharge as a
CO, which he received in
October of 1969 after two years'
service.

Joseph Sisco
By BILL ABBOTT
Joseph Sisco's symposium
talk Wednesday stressed that an
overall settlement in the MidEast could not be achieved in
the near future, but emphasized
that the success of the present
cease-fire on the Egyptian-Israeli
front is a step toward interim
settlement.
Sisco also stated that the U.S.
is maintaining the military
balance of power, as well as
acting as a catalyst in mediating
settlement attempts. He stressed
that active American diplomacy
in the Mid-East "is a most
important and successful
deterrent."
Many in the audience came
loaded with questions regarding
the plight of Soviet Jews. Sisco
avoided the topic in his speech,
but, in answering questions, he
maintained' that a policy of
discretion would be most
effective one for the United
States to pursue.
He emphasized America's
"quiet diplomacy" which
recognizes the importance of
maintaining good relations with
Russia.
The core of Sisco's speech was
concerned with the problem of
establishing an interim settlemnt
in the Mid-East. President Nixon
is adamant, that "differences
must be settled by the Arab
nations and Israel and not by the
super powers," he said.
Sisco cited two primary
factors responsible in delaying a
temporary settlement; the
mistrust between the Arabs and
Israelis, and the "constant
specter of confrontation
•

between the superpowers."
Sisco maintained since both
sides share a parallel interest in
avoiding con flict between the U.S.
and Russia, "it ought to be
possible to work out pragmatic
compromises."
"Not only has Egypt
expressed a desire to sign a peace
agreement," he asserted, "but
also the Sadat government is
more concerned with internal
development than external
expansion."

Computer program
The controversy surrounding the future of Computer
Sciences is not easy to assess. Computers will obviously be
of great importance in the future. Over 250
undergraduates are involved in their courses this semester
as well as 60 Evening College students working for the new
Master of Science degree. These students are depending on
these courses for part of their education. But a commitment by the University for undefined financial responsibilities in the future would be indefensible with an unclear
financial future. This sort of planning has gotten the University into difficulties in the past.
The one aspect of Dean Benton's decision that does
seem clearcut concerns the lack of public review or consultation before the decision was reached. The Academic
Council was consulted in this decision, but they chose to
consider the evaluation of the program purely budgetary,
despite the fact that the decision had the academic effect
of wiping out two new undergraduate programs. The decision was thus placed in Benton's hands.

SAC fee
The death by apathy of the rise in the student activity
fee, and the refusal by the administration to reconsider its
elimination of its subsidy of the student activities program,
brings on something of a crisis in Hopkins life. Now nearly
unbearable, the creative and social environment on campus
would travel even further downhill if the monetary
situation does not improve. Having failed at getting the
undergraduates or the administration to foot the bill,
perhaps thet student leaders should look to another
alternative. There are other groups on campus besides the
undergraduates who benefit from student
activities—faculty and grad students get to pick up the
News-Letter for free, they pay reduced rates at
Barnstormers plays and SC concerts, which are subsidized
by activity funds, as well as benefiting from the
innumerable small groups and organizations around
campus. Yet the undergraduate is forced to pay for all of
these. And when the time comes for an increase, they ask
the undergrads for more. Perhaps, instead, faculty and
particularly graduate students could pay something for the
services they receive. Of course these groups should not be
forced to pay as much as the undergraduates who now
shell out $25 each year. But it would seem fair to charge
these groups $5 or $10 per annum, and it would go a long
way towards solving the current financial woes of student
activities.

With his "grand finale."
Kramer's latest film, which he
produced and directed is based
on a novel called "Bless the
Beasts and Children," by
Glendon Swarthout. The author
lives in Arizona, and the setting
is at a boy's camp in his home
state. The novel essentially deals
With the growth and maturation,

are placed in the same cabin

cowboy." The filming was done

Island, where a herd of 400
buffalo roam.
In 1925, 19 of them were

Buffalo Thinned
The film recounts the

adventures of these six boys as
they try to save a herd of
buffalo from being "thinned" by
shooting some of them in a
fenced pasture.
This is a process actually in
use by the Arizona Game and
Fish Department on their
15,000 acre Raymond Ranch
game preserve. Every year, the
state holds a lottery to see who
gets to shoot the buffalo. In
1970, 80 were destined to be
killed, and 474 hunters applied.
For $45, the gunner may fire at
the doomed herd from a •
distance of 10 to 50 yards. He
may keep the head, hide and
front quarter of "his" buffalo,
with the remaining meat being
sold to the public.
In the film, this hunt is the
catalyzing incident. When the six
boys are taken to see it by their
counselor, who himself is one of
the gunners, they are totally
repulsed by their experience and
they resolve to come back and
• free the rest of the1 buffalo.

headset radio given to Wheaties,
their counselor, who keeps it on

southwestern countryside, and

steal an old extermination
company jeep. It carries a very
apropos red flag with an upside
down bug and the words—"we
kill 'em dead."
Kramer reveals the emotional
disturbances in the boys' pasts
by a series of flashbacks, some
of which are very funny, while
others border on farce, as in
Lally 2's gluttonous gobbling of
a huge dish of candy in about 20
seconds in the psychiatrist's
office.

front quarter of "his" buffalo,
with the remaining meat being
sold to the public.
